Will the metaverse open the door to targeted ads using biometric data?11/3/2021

Brands are already staking out the commercial opportunities within the metaverse but some experts are raising the alarm about the implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent.

Advertising, GDPR, Virtual reality, Data protection, Facebook, Metaverse, next_biztech-newsArchivedRead

    "@graph": [
        {
            "@type": "NewsArticle",
            "mainEntityOfPage": {
                "@type": "Webpage",
                "url": "https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/12/03/reading-your-mind-how-eyes-pupils-and-heart-rate-could-be-used-to-target-ads-in-the-metave"
            },
            "headline": "\u2018Reading your mind\u2019: How eyes, pupils and heart rate could be used to target ads in the metaverse",
            "description": "Brands are already staking out the commercial opportunities within the metaverse but some experts are raising the alarm about the implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent.",
            "articleBody": "If we\u2019ve learned anything about new means of communication over the last century, it\u2019s that where technology attracts people\u2019s eyes and ears, advertisers won\u2019t be long chasing after them. It\u2019s been the case with radio, cinema, TV, the Internet and social media, so it seems almost impossible that it won\u2019t be the case in the so-called  metaverse  - the new fully realised, shared universe that companies like Meta are proposing to build. In perhaps a sign of things to come, a host of brands have already dipped their toes into gaming metaverses, hosting virtual fashion shows and dropping exclusive collections in game. Luxury fashion houses like Louis Vuitton, Valentino and Marc Jacobs have all designed digital items for the social simulation game Animal Crossing - and Balenciaga has collaborated with Fortnite on an exclusive drop of wearable skins for in-game characters, to name but a few. \u2018Think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement\u2019 But now that Meta, a targeted advertising powerhouse, has staked its claim to the metaverse, some experts are raising the alarm about the specific implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent. \u201cWhen you think about advertising in XR, you should think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement,\u201d Brittan Heller, counsel with American law firm Foley Hoag and an expert in privacy and safety in immersive environments, told Euronews Next. \u201cThe way that advertising works in these contexts is a little different because you seek out the experiences. You like the experiences,\u201d she explained. \u201cAn ad in virtual reality may look like buying a designer jacket for your digital avatar [but] that's an ad for a clothing company that you are wearing on your body\u201d. \u201cIt may look like buying a game that puts you into Jurassic Park - [but] what better way to advertise the movie franchise than to actually put you in the experience of being in Jurassic Park?\u201d What is biometric psychography? The problem here, according to Heller, is that in the metaverse, the capability for harvesting biometric data and using that sensitive data to target ads tailored to you, goes far beyond the considerable amount of data Facebook already uses to build our consumer profiles. If the technology that Meta is promising comes to fruition, the possibility exists that a form of targeted advertising which tracks involuntary biological responses could be proliferated. For VR headsets to work in this environment, Heller says, they will have to be able to track your pupils and your eyes. This means advertisements could be tailored according to what attracts or holds your visual attention and how you physically respond to it. Heller has coined a term for this combination of one\u2019s biometric information with targeted advertising: biometric psychography. If an entity had access to biometric data such as pupil dilation, skin moistness, EKG or heart rate - bodily indicators that happen involuntarily in response to stimuli - and combined it with existing targeted advertising datasets, it would be \u201cakin to reading your mind,\u201d Heller said. \u201cThe type of information you can get from somebody's pupil dilation, for example - that can tell you whether or not somebody is telling the truth. It can tell you whether or not somebody is sexually attracted to the person that they're seeing,\u201d she explained. \u201cWe're rapidly moving into a space where your intentions and your thoughts are substantial data sets that have technological importance in a way that they didn't before\u201d. \u201cThe risk that I think we've learnt from Cambridge Analytica is that privacy risks come into play when you have the combination of unanticipated data sets, especially when you're looking at emerging technology\u201d. Regulating the metaverse Heller believes that biometric laws in the United States are insufficient in protecting users from use or misuse of this kind of data because \u201cbiometrics laws in the States are defined by protecting your identity, not protecting your thoughts or your impulses\u201d. With the metaverse, the risk remains that the pace of development of the technology will outstrip the ability of institutions to regulate them effectively as has arguably been the case with social media platforms. In light of the fact that companies hoping to build the metaverse are multinational and operate across borders, Heller believes the most effective way to deal with these issues of user protection is a \u201chuman rights based approach\u201d. \u201cThere are many stakeholders in this, there's civil society, there are public groups, there are governments and then there are intergovernmental organisations as well,\u201d she explained. \u201cA human rights approach has been the way that we've been able to bring all of these players and their concerns together and make sure that everybody is heard\u201d. But what can companies do to protect people in the metaverse? If tech organisations are serious about guaranteeing users' digital rights in immersive environments, it will depend on them being open about the technology they are developing. \u201cI would want companies to be more transparent with the functionality of their technologies, not just their intentions and their business plans, but how this will work,\u201d Heller said. \u201cThat will help lawmakers ask the questions that they need to protect the public and to cooperate with each other for trans border technology\u201d.",

    ><div class="o-section o-article jsArticleFirst theme-biztech-news type- u-padding-top-xlarge-5" data-nid="1758054" data-cid="6278538" data-related="2"><header class="o-article__header"><div class="o-article__labels"><div class="c-article-labels c-article-labels c-article-labels"><div class="media__body__label
          u-margin-bottom-large-2"><a class="media__body__cat" href="//www.euronews.com/next/biztech-news">Biztech news</a></div></div></div><h1 class="c-article-title u-text-align--start">
    ‘Reading your mind’: How eyes, pupils and heart rate could be used to target ads in the metaverse
</h1></header><div class="o-article__body o-article__body--magazine"><div><div class="c-article__full_article"><div class="jsTopArticle c-article-media c-article-media--magazine u-margin-top-0 js-article-video" data-sponsored="Partner content"><div class="jsTopArticleMain"><div class="c-video-player u-position-relative u-bg-grey4"><div class="c-video-player__container"><img class="c-article-media__img u-max-height-full u-width-full"

  src="https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/06/27/85/38/400x225_cmsv2_37ef0b86-7f8c-59eb-8857-01961f72b10f-6278538.jpg"
  srcset="https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/06/27/85/38/400x225_cmsv2_37ef0b86-7f8c-59eb-8857-01961f72b10f-6278538.jpg 400w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/06/27/85/38/800x450_cmsv2_37ef0b86-7f8c-59eb-8857-01961f72b10f-6278538.jpg 800w, https://static.euronews.com/articles/stories/06/27/85/38/1100x619_cmsv2_37ef0b86-7f8c-59eb-8857-01961f72b10f-6278538.jpg 1100w"
  sizes="(max-width: 375px) 100vw, (max-width: 768px) 100vw, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, (max-width: 1280px) 100vw"
            importance="high"
     title="Some experts are raising the alarm about what targeted advertising could look like in the Meta metaverse." alt="Some experts are raising the alarm about what targeted advertising could look like in the Meta metaverse." width="320" height="180"></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-media-copyright u-margin-top-1 "><span class="c-caption">
    Some experts are raising the alarm about what targeted advertising could look like in the Meta metaverse.
</span>
                              -  
                            <span class="c-copyright"><span class="c-copyright__label">Copyright</span> 
        <a class="c-copyright__link" href="#">Canva</a></span></div><div class="c-article__container jsBottomArticle"><div class="u-show-for-medium"></div><div class="js-responsive-iframes-container"><div class="o-article__body__container u-margin-x-auto"><div class="u-margin-bottom-3 u-margin-top-3 u-margin-x-0 u-margin-top-medium-4 u-margin-top-xlarge-5"><div class="c-article-contributors">
          By <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://twitter.com/euronews"><b>Aisling Ní Chúláin</b></a><time class="c-article-date" data-timestamp="1638526591" datetime="2021-12-03"><span class="c-article-date__bullet">  •  </span><span class="c-article-date__last-updated-label">Updated:</span> 03/12/2021
    </time></div></div><div class="c-article-content c-article-content--next js-article-content "><div class="c-article-content__first-element"></div><p>If we’ve learned anything about new means of communication over the last century, it’s that where technology attracts people’s eyes and ears, advertisers won’t be long chasing after them.</p><p>It’s been the case with radio, cinema, TV, the Internet and social media, so it seems almost impossible that it won’t be the case in the so-called <a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/11/19/meta-is-laying-claim-to-the-metaverse-others-have-already-beat-mark-zuckerberg-to-it"><strong>metaverse</strong></a> - the new fully realised, shared universe that companies like Meta are proposing to build.</p><p>In perhaps a sign of things to come, a host of brands have already dipped their toes into gaming metaverses, hosting virtual fashion shows and dropping exclusive collections in game.</p><div class="c-advertising-sticky-floor"><div data-ad-name="adzone-sticky-floor" 
        data-ad-index="0"  
        class="advertising advertising--no-label js-adzone"></div><button class="c-advertising-sticky-floor__btn-close" type="button" aria-label="Close advertising" onclick="this.parentElement.classList.add('u-hide-for-all')"><svg class="c-advertising-sticky-floor__btn-close__svg" width="10" height="10" viewBox="0 0 17 17" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="m16.6 15-6.5-6.5 6.4-6.5c0.4-0.4 0.4-1.2 0-1.6s-1.2-0.4-1.6 0l-6.4 6.5-6.5-6.5c-0.4-0.4-1.2-0.4-1.6 0s-0.4 1.2 0 1.6l6.5 6.5-6.6 6.5c-0.4 0.4-0.4 1.2 0 1.6s1.2 0.4 1.6 0l6.5-6.5 6.5 6.5c0.4 0.4 1.2 0.4 1.6 0 0.5-0.4 0.5-1.2 0.1-1.6z"/></svg></button></div><div data-ad-name="adzone-outstream" class="advertising advertising--no-label js-adzone outstream"></div><p>Luxury fashion houses like Louis Vuitton, Valentino and Marc Jacobs have all designed digital items for the social simulation game Animal Crossing - and Balenciaga has collaborated with Fortnite on an exclusive drop of wearable skins for in-game characters, to name but a few.</p><h2>‘Think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement’</h2><p>But now that Meta, a targeted advertising powerhouse, has staked its claim to the metaverse, some experts are raising the alarm about the specific implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent.</p><p>“When you think about advertising in XR, you should think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement,” Brittan Heller, counsel with American law firm Foley Hoag and an expert in privacy and safety in immersive environments, told Euronews Next.</p><p>“The way that advertising works in these contexts is a little different because you seek out the experiences. You like the experiences,” she explained.</p><div class="advertising advertising--no-label advertising--sharethrough js-adzone" data-ad-name="adzone-sharethrough" data-ad-index="1" data-ad-key="strnativekey" data-ad-key-value="1G96EdRgcHV6pyWWMGCR7SB7"></div><div class="widget widget--type-quotation
    widget--size-medium
    widget--align-right"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__content"><blockquote class="widget__quote"><span class="widget__quoteText">We're rapidly moving into a space where your intentions and your thoughts are substantial data sets that have technological importance in a way that they didn't before.</span></blockquote><cite class="widget__author"><div class="widget__authorText">
                        Brittan Heller
                    </div><div class="widget__author_descriptionText">
                        Human Rights Counsel - Foley Hoag LLP
                    </div></cite></div></div></div><p>“An ad in virtual reality may look like buying a designer jacket for your digital avatar [but] that's an ad for a clothing company that you are wearing on your body”.</p><p>“It may look like buying a game that puts you into Jurassic Park - [but] what better way to advertise the movie franchise than to actually put you in the experience of being in Jurassic Park?”</p><div data-stories-id="6200822,6217520" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/11/19/meta-is-laying-claim-to-the-metaverse-others-have-already-beat-mark-zuckerberg-to-it">Enter the metaverse: We explain the vision for the next version of the Internet</a></li><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/11/10/seoul-to-become-the-first-city-to-enter-the-metaverse-what-will-it-look-like">Seoul to become the first city to enter the metaverse. What will it look like?</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><h2>What is biometric psychography?</h2><p>The problem here, according to Heller, is that in the metaverse, the capability for harvesting biometric data and using that sensitive data to target ads tailored to you, goes far beyond the considerable amount of data Facebook already uses to build our consumer profiles.</p><p>If the technology that Meta is promising comes to fruition, the possibility exists that a form of targeted advertising which tracks involuntary biological responses could be proliferated.</p><div class="widget widget--type-quotation
    widget--size-medium
    widget--align-left"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__content"><blockquote class="widget__quote"><span class="widget__quoteText">The risk that I think we've learnt from Cambridge Analytica is that privacy risks come into play when you have the combination of unanticipated data sets, especially when you're looking at emerging technology.</span></blockquote><cite class="widget__author"><div class="widget__authorText">
                        Brittan Heller
                    </div><div class="widget__author_descriptionText">
                        Human Rights Counsel - Foley Hoag LLP
                    </div></cite></div></div></div><p>For VR headsets to work in this environment, Heller says, they will have to be able to track your pupils and your eyes.</p><div class="ads small-12 column text-center show-for-small-only u-show-for-small-only"><div class="enw-MPU "><div data-ad-name="adzone-mpu" data-ad-index="1" class="enw-MPU__img advertising js-adzone"></div></div></div><p>This means advertisements could be tailored according to what attracts or holds your visual attention and how you physically respond to it.</p><p>Heller has coined a term for this combination of one’s biometric information with targeted advertising: biometric psychography.</p><p>If an entity had access to biometric data such as pupil dilation, skin moistness, EKG or heart rate - bodily indicators that happen involuntarily in response to stimuli - and combined it with existing targeted advertising datasets, it would be “akin to reading your mind,” Heller said.</p><p>“The type of information you can get from somebody's pupil dilation, for example - that can tell you whether or not somebody is telling the truth. It can tell you whether or not somebody is sexually attracted to the person that they're seeing,” she explained.</p><p>“We're rapidly moving into a space where your intentions and your thoughts are substantial data sets that have technological importance in a way that they didn't before”.</p><div class="ads small-12 column text-center show-for-small-only u-show-for-small-only"><div class="enw-MPU "><div data-ad-name="adzone-mpu" data-ad-index="2" class="enw-MPU__img advertising js-adzone"></div></div></div><p>“The risk that I think we've learnt from Cambridge Analytica is that privacy risks come into play when you have the combination of unanticipated data sets, especially when you're looking at emerging technology”.</p><div data-stories-id="6252444" data-event="widget_related" class="widget widget--type-related widget--size-fullwidth widget--align-center"><div class="widget__wrapper"><div class="widget__ratio widget__ratio--auto"><div class="widget__contents"><ul class="widget__related_list"><li class="widget__related_listItem"><a href="https://www.euronews.com/next/2021/11/29/welcome-to-decentraland-the-metaverse-world-with-its-own-crypto-where-land-is-worth-millio">Welcome to Decentraland, the metaverse world with its own crypto where 'land' is worth millions</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><h2>Regulating the metaverse</h2><p>Heller believes that biometric laws in the United States are insufficient in protecting users from use or misuse of this kind of data because “biometrics laws in the States are defined by protecting your identity, not protecting your thoughts or your impulses”.</p><p>With the metaverse, the risk remains that the pace of development of the technology will outstrip the ability of institutions to regulate them effectively as has arguably been the case with social media platforms.</p><p>In light of the fact that companies hoping to build the metaverse are multinational and operate across borders, Heller believes the most effective way to deal with these issues of user protection is a “human rights based approach”.</p><p>“There are many stakeholders in this, there's civil society, there are public groups, there are governments and then there are intergovernmental organisations as well,” she explained.</p><div class="ads small-12 column text-center show-for-small-only u-show-for-small-only"><div class="enw-MPU "><div data-ad-name="adzone-mpu" data-ad-index="3" class="enw-MPU__img advertising js-adzone"></div></div></div><p>“A human rights approach has been the way that we've been able to bring all of these players and their concerns together and make sure that everybody is heard”.</p><p>But what can companies do to protect people in the metaverse?</p><p>If tech organisations are serious about guaranteeing users' digital rights in immersive environments, it will depend on them being open about the technology they are developing.</p><p>“I would want companies to be more transparent with the functionality of their technologies, not just their intentions and their business plans, but how this will work,” Heller said.</p><p>“That will help lawmakers ask the questions that they need to protect the public and to cooperate with each other for trans border technology”.</p></div><div class="clear"></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article__container"><div class="u-show-for-medium"></div><footer readabilityObject.title: Will the metaverse open the door to targeted ads using biometric data?
readabilityObject.content:
If we’ve learned anything about new means of communication over the last century, it’s that where technology attracts people’s eyes and ears, advertisers won’t be long chasing after them.

It’s been the case with radio, cinema, TV, the Internet and social media, so it seems almost impossible that it won’t be the case in the so-called metaverse - the new fully realised, shared universe that companies like Meta are proposing to build.

In perhaps a sign of things to come, a host of brands have already dipped their toes into gaming metaverses, hosting virtual fashion shows and dropping exclusive collections in game.

Luxury fashion houses like Louis Vuitton, Valentino and Marc Jacobs have all designed digital items for the social simulation game Animal Crossing - and Balenciaga has collaborated with Fortnite on an exclusive drop of wearable skins for in-game characters, to name but a few.

‘Think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement’

But now that Meta, a targeted advertising powerhouse, has staked its claim to the metaverse, some experts are raising the alarm about the specific implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent.

“When you think about advertising in XR, you should think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement,” Brittan Heller, counsel with American law firm Foley Hoag and an expert in privacy and safety in immersive environments, told Euronews Next.

“The way that advertising works in these contexts is a little different because you seek out the experiences. You like the experiences,” she explained.

“An ad in virtual reality may look like buying a designer jacket for your digital avatar [but] that's an ad for a clothing company that you are wearing on your body”.

“It may look like buying a game that puts you into Jurassic Park - [but] what better way to advertise the movie franchise than to actually put you in the experience of being in Jurassic Park?”

What is biometric psychography?

The problem here, according to Heller, is that in the metaverse, the capability for harvesting biometric data and using that sensitive data to target ads tailored to you, goes far beyond the considerable amount of data Facebook already uses to build our consumer profiles.

If the technology that Meta is promising comes to fruition, the possibility exists that a form of targeted advertising which tracks involuntary biological responses could be proliferated.

For VR headsets to work in this environment, Heller says, they will have to be able to track your pupils and your eyes.

This means advertisements could be tailored according to what attracts or holds your visual attention and how you physically respond to it.

Heller has coined a term for this combination of one’s biometric information with targeted advertising: biometric psychography.

If an entity had access to biometric data such as pupil dilation, skin moistness, EKG or heart rate - bodily indicators that happen involuntarily in response to stimuli - and combined it with existing targeted advertising datasets, it would be “akin to reading your mind,” Heller said.

“The type of information you can get from somebody's pupil dilation, for example - that can tell you whether or not somebody is telling the truth. It can tell you whether or not somebody is sexually attracted to the person that they're seeing,” she explained.

“We're rapidly moving into a space where your intentions and your thoughts are substantial data sets that have technological importance in a way that they didn't before”.

“The risk that I think we've learnt from Cambridge Analytica is that privacy risks come into play when you have the combination of unanticipated data sets, especially when you're looking at emerging technology”.

Regulating the metaverse

Heller believes that biometric laws in the United States are insufficient in protecting users from use or misuse of this kind of data because “biometrics laws in the States are defined by protecting your identity, not protecting your thoughts or your impulses”.

With the metaverse, the risk remains that the pace of development of the technology will outstrip the ability of institutions to regulate them effectively as has arguably been the case with social media platforms.

In light of the fact that companies hoping to build the metaverse are multinational and operate across borders, Heller believes the most effective way to deal with these issues of user protection is a “human rights based approach”.

“There are many stakeholders in this, there's civil society, there are public groups, there are governments and then there are intergovernmental organisations as well,” she explained.

“A human rights approach has been the way that we've been able to bring all of these players and their concerns together and make sure that everybody is heard”.

But what can companies do to protect people in the metaverse?

If tech organisations are serious about guaranteeing users' digital rights in immersive environments, it will depend on them being open about the technology they are developing.

“I would want companies to be more transparent with the functionality of their technologies, not just their intentions and their business plans, but how this will work,” Heller said.

“That will help lawmakers ask the questions that they need to protect the public and to cooperate with each other for trans border technology”.

@graph.headline: ‘Reading your mind’: How eyes, pupils and heart rate could be used to target ads in the metaverse
@graph.description: Brands are already staking out the commercial opportunities within the metaverse but some experts are raising the alarm about the implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent.
@graph.articleBody: If we’ve learned anything about new means of communication over the last century, it’s that where technology attracts people’s eyes and ears, advertisers won’t be long chasing after them. It’s been the case with radio, cinema, TV, the Internet and social media, so it seems almost impossible that it won’t be the case in the so-called  metaverse  - the new fully realised, shared universe that companies like Meta are proposing to build. In perhaps a sign of things to come, a host of brands have already dipped their toes into gaming metaverses, hosting virtual fashion shows and dropping exclusive collections in game. Luxury fashion houses like Louis Vuitton, Valentino and Marc Jacobs have all designed digital items for the social simulation game Animal Crossing - and Balenciaga has collaborated with Fortnite on an exclusive drop of wearable skins for in-game characters, to name but a few. ‘Think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement’ But now that Meta, a targeted advertising powerhouse, has staked its claim to the metaverse, some experts are raising the alarm about the specific implications immersive advertising will have for user privacy, safety and consent. “When you think about advertising in XR, you should think about it as placement in the product instead of product placement,” Brittan Heller, counsel with American law firm Foley Hoag and an expert in privacy and safety in immersive environments, told Euronews Next. “The way that advertising works in these contexts is a little different because you seek out the experiences. You like the experiences,” she explained. “An ad in virtual reality may look like buying a designer jacket for your digital avatar [but] that's an ad for a clothing company that you are wearing on your body”. “It may look like buying a game that puts you into Jurassic Park - [but] what better way to advertise the movie franchise than to actually put you in the experience of being in Jurassic Park?” What is biometric psychography? The problem here, according to Heller, is that in the metaverse, the capability for harvesting biometric data and using that sensitive data to target ads tailored to you, goes far beyond the considerable amount of data Facebook already uses to build our consumer profiles. If the technology that Meta is promising comes to fruition, the possibility exists that a form of targeted advertising which tracks involuntary biological responses could be proliferated. For VR headsets to work in this environment, Heller says, they will have to be able to track your pupils and your eyes. This means advertisements could be tailored according to what attracts or holds your visual attention and how you physically respond to it. Heller has coined a term for this combination of one’s biometric information with targeted advertising: biometric psychography. If an entity had access to biometric data such as pupil dilation, skin moistness, EKG or heart rate - bodily indicators that happen involuntarily in response to stimuli - and combined it with existing targeted advertising datasets, it would be “akin to reading your mind,” Heller said. “The type of information you can get from somebody's pupil dilation, for example - that can tell you whether or not somebody is telling the truth. It can tell you whether or not somebody is sexually attracted to the person that they're seeing,” she explained. “We're rapidly moving into a space where your intentions and your thoughts are substantial data sets that have technological importance in a way that they didn't before”. “The risk that I think we've learnt from Cambridge Analytica is that privacy risks come into play when you have the combination of unanticipated data sets, especially when you're looking at emerging technology”. Regulating the metaverse Heller believes that biometric laws in the United States are insufficient in protecting users from use or misuse of this kind of data because “biometrics laws in the States are defined by protecting your identity, not protecting your thoughts or your impulses”. With the metaverse, the risk remains that the pace of development of the technology will outstrip the ability of institutions to regulate them effectively as has arguably been the case with social media platforms. In light of the fact that companies hoping to build the metaverse are multinational and operate across borders, Heller believes the most effective way to deal with these issues of user protection is a “human rights based approach”. “There are many stakeholders in this, there's civil society, there are public groups, there are governments and then there are intergovernmental organisations as well,” she explained. “A human rights approach has been the way that we've been able to bring all of these players and their concerns together and make sure that everybody is heard”. But what can companies do to protect people in the metaverse? If tech organisations are serious about guaranteeing users' digital rights in immersive environments, it will depend on them being open about the technology they are developing. “I would want companies to be more transparent with the functionality of their technologies, not just their intentions and their business plans, but how this will work,” Heller said. “That will help lawmakers ask the questions that they need to protect the public and to cooperate with each other for trans border technology”.
